title.narrative: Joint UNISFA-IOM Partnership for a Project for Local Face Mask Production

description.narrative: Through provision of face masks and community outreach, this project contributes to the prevention of COVID-19 in Abyei Administrative Area. Activities focus on distribution of face masks and community awareness raising. The proposed project is an initiative in response to the COVID-19 global pandemic that seeks to empower and build the capacity of women to engage in income generating activities through the local production of face masks, promotion of women's role in prevention of COVID-19, and creation of awareness on prevention of COVID-19, specially targeting the most vulnerable groups in the communities. The project is a partnership programme with the United Nations Interim Security Force for Abyei (UNISFA) and contributes to an existing community stabilization project in Abyei.

title.narrative: Assessing and Addressing the Impacts of COVID-19 on Societies, Economies and Vulnerable Groups in Countries of the Middle East and North Africa Region

description.narrative: To help mitigate the socio-economic impacts of COVID-19, IOM is implementing this regional project in the Middle East and North Africa (MENA) with the aim to respond to the financial and socio-economic impact of disruptions of COVID-19 on migrant, displaced populations and host communities in the region. In particular, IOM is: (1) conducting research and providing technical support through cash-based interventions in early recovery and post crisis contexts in the region; (2) developing regional research products on the socio-economic impact of COVID-19 on different countries in the MENA region; and 3) improving the understanding of existing social protection schemes in the MENA region in terms of their accessibility for migrants and displaced populations, of particular concern being migrants and displaced populations in the informal economy.

In particular, IOM aims to support them through the development of economic activities, and improvement of economic capacities of host communities with adequate support for their resilience and integration in the decision-making process of their community. Through this project, IOM is also supporting the Government in the implementation of its national strategy to combat the spread of the COVID-19 epidemic by carrying out some activities to strengthen the prevention of the spread of COVID-19 among refugees and host communities. Particular attention is being paid to inclusion of gender considerations in the project needs analysis, design, implementation, monitoring and evaluation to enhance relevance and impact of the action for the targeted communities.

title.narrative: Costa Rica: Local Recycling Knowledge Transfer in San Juan, Ciudad Quesada

description.narrative: The objective of this project is to foster social cohesion and integration for migrant populations through local knowledge sharing and economic empowerment related to recycling in the San Juan neighborhood of Quesada City (Costa Rica). Prevailing poverty, unemployment, an absence of law enforcement, widespread violence and crime, and the regular arrival of migrants to the area, have caused this neighborhood to near a potential crisis situation. This has been exacerbated by the COVID-19 pandemic, as it has created a socioeconomic downturn which is adversely affecting all of Costa Rican society, and a burden that is falling heaviest on migrants. The foundation of this project is based on initiatives already underway in San Juan to empower women in the community as drivers of economic and social development. IOM aims to expand the impact of the San Juan Recycling Center, a cooperative formed by Nicaraguan women, by introducing value added processes and encouraging the transfer of recycling knowledge.

title.narrative: Community Stabilization Through Returned Migrant Reintegration in Kyrgyzstan and Tajikistan During and After COVID-19

description.narrative: Heavy socioeconomic impacts resulting from COVID-19 travel restrictions are pushing migrant families into poverty in Central Asia. Many migrants are already experiencing great stress associated with failed migration and increased competition for the jobs available. Large numbers of unemployed migrants having faced COVID-19 pressures, may negatively impact social cohesion, such as some turning to crime or exacerbating existing discontent amongst the cohort of returning migrants and the communities to which they return. Through this project, IOM aims to utilise a proven methodology for migrant engagement and reintegration planning to work with returned migrants in five localities of the Osh, Jalal-Abad and Batken regions of Kyrgyzstan and targeted communities of the Gorno-Badakhshan Autonomous Oblast of Tajikistan. In addition, IOM engages with community structures to build social cohesion and provide targeted assistance and support to cases displaying high vulnerability to poverty, crime, or conflict.

title.narrative: Police Professionalization and Community Policing in the Democratic Republic of the Congo - Phase IV

description.narrative: The goal of Phase IV of this project is to contribute to the improvement of security governance and the rule of law in Lubumbashi, Mbuji Mayi, Goma and Bukavu In the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) by supporting security sector reform and police professionalization. In light of the evolving security and public health context in the DRC, the project seeks to implement the remaining training activities of the previous phase in addition to expanding the community policing approach and using it to strengthen the police's COVID-19 response. As such the project will focus on; capacity development of security actors, including police services, civilian authorities, and community members; strengthening of good security governance and the rule of law according to the community policing system and principles; and support to security actors involved in the enforcement of the COVID-19 response plan including any restrictions taken by the Government.

title.narrative: IOM Crisis Response Platform
Strengthening the Resilience of Vulnerable Populations (Migrants, Refugees, IDPs, Returnees, Etc.) and the Health Response to the COVID-19 Emergency

description.narrative: Through this project, IOM supports governments in the Republic of Colombia, the Republic of Ecuador and the Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela in their COVID-19 responses to foster resilience, promote integration by improving the health response, community engagement and environmental protection of affected communities. Specifically, IOM improves access to health services by enhancing the capacity of prioritized health centres and temporary shelters; enhances governments' response capacities to address conflict sensitivity challenges caused by the COVID-19 pandemic; promotes peaceful co-existence and combats xenophobia through community-based interventions aimed at increasing the resilience of host communities; and coordinates and enables a comprehensive and effective response by national and international actors to the pandemic and its aftermath.

title.narrative: IOM Crisis Response Platform
Prevention of the Transmission of COVID-19 and the Reduction of the Community Tensions Linked to COVID-19 in High Risk Border Areas of the Central African Republic

description.narrative: The main objective of this project is to help prevent the local transmission of COVID-19 by raising awareness among populations particularly exposed in the border areas in the Central African Republic (CAR). Concretely, it aims to increase information and awareness to access prevention and treatment services for COVID-19. The project is implemented in close collaboration with the national committee for the management of the COVID-19 crisis and is necessary because of disinformation and rumors that reduce the effectiveness of the COVID-19 control programs implemented by the Ministry of Health. By targeting populations particularly vulnerable to COVID-19, people with pre-existing diseases such as diabetics, tuberculosis patients and people living with HIV with a view to heightened awareness and referral to health services available, the project contributes to a targeted response to COVID-19 in CAR.

title.narrative: Promoting Peaceful Coexistence in the COVID-19 Response for Migrants, Refugees and Other Vulnerable Populations in Central America and the Caribbean

description.narrative: Implemented through a Multi-Partner Contribution Agreement with IOM and the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR), this project aims to promote integration and peaceful coexistence by improving the health response, community engagement and the protection of affected communities in Latin America and the Caribbean, particularly El Salvador, Honduras, Nicaragua, Panama, and Haiti. The COVID-19 pandemic has had vast impacts on the socioeconomic well-being and health of the region's population, affecting the considerable number of vulnerable populations most including indigenous populations, stranded migrants, returnees, refugees, asylum seekers, internally displaced persons, and vulnerable host/transit community members. While each country faces distinct challenges, there is an overall need to support governments in their COVID-19 responses in order to ensure these populations are not left behind. Risk of conflict and insecurity is high because of the pandemic's wide-ranging effects on a region characterized by insecurity, violence, and limited institutional capacity. As borders remain partially or completely closed and health systems are overwhelmed, IOM and UNHCR have the operational capacity in the region and the institutional expertise to support governments in their efforts to mitigate conflict as a result of the pandemic.

title.narrative: Promoting Location-Specific Inclusion in Iraq

description.narrative: In order to promote the stabilization of conflict-affected communities and/or other communities with intensive needs based on conflict assessments previously conducted by IOM Iraq’s Community Stabilization Unit, IOM seeks to provide the Government of Iraq with support to address two of the country’s most pressing challenges of reintegration of families with a perceived affiliation to ISIL to return to and co-exist with their communities of origin and other conflict-affected communities (a secondary location of settlement), while also bolstering resilience to future waves of violent extremism within these communities; and the socio-economic reintegration of former combatants who have spontaneously disengaged and returned to their area of origin. In addition, IOM provides assistance to vulnerable communities in Iraq to sustain peace in the context of COVID-19 by addressing socio-economic impacts brought on by the pandemic.

description.narrative: To support vulnerable populations including Syrian refugees and the Turkish host communities, and to strengthen Turkey’s border management system, IOM aims to support a comprehensive protection and capacity building response through the provision of continued support to Ensar Community Centre in Gaziantep through support to establish a Municipal Migrant and Women’s Support Centre in Kilis; and the rollout of innovative activities in the Sanliurfa Migrant Information and Coordination Centre. Additionally, the project will provide an entrepreneurship training program for Syrian refugees and host community members with disabilities in Gaziantep, increase access to basic services through infrastructure rehabilitation, and border management capacity building at Turkey’s eastern borders and Istanbul Airport. Overall, IOM aims to target 14,505 beneficiaries.

title.narrative: Provision of Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH) and Shelter-NFI Emergency Supplies for Flood Affected Populations in South Sudan

description.narrative: IOM, as the Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH) and Shelter/Non-Food Items (S/NFI) Pipeline agency supports OCHA and the Clusters to provide frontline life-saving assistance within the immediate South Sudan flood response through provision and transportation of in-kind WASH and S/NFI supplies. With CERF funding, IOM’s Pipeline is procuring the core WASH and S/NFI items to replenish the supplies released in the form of flood survival items for affected people targeted by WASH and S/NFI Cluster. The project is in line with the CERF and WASH and S/NFI Clusters’ sector specific objectives as it prioritizes the most urgent and life-saving WASH static and mobile responses, as well as adequate shelter and appropriate NFI supplies for newly displaced or vulnerable populations as well as host communities who are unable to meet their basic WASH and emergency shelter and NFI needs as a result of the massive floods in the country. Following WHO’s declaration of COVID-19 as pandemic, and the establishment of the COVID-19 Taskforce in South Sudan, IOM Pipeline in coordination with both S/NFI and WASH Clusters, is scaling up activities to complement efforts on COVID-19 preparedness and response actions.

title.narrative: IOM Crisis Response Platform
Lifesaving Emergency Assistance to Vulnerable Migrants Affected by Floods in Djibouti

description.narrative: Under this project IOM will identify vulnerable migrant households in need of assistance and through voucher system will target households with emergency non-food items (NFIs), including water, sanitation and hygiene (WASH) items, and shelter repair kits. In addition, Djibouti has seen the rapid escalation of COVID-19 confirmed case in the past few weeks. The particular migration profile of the country, being the common migratory route from Ethiopia to Saudi Arabia for many travellers by land, and the closure of borders, put at risk a greater number of migrants transiting through Djibouti and unable to travel to their country of destination. Given the challenging situation that is anticipated, the Government of Djibouti has sought the support of IOM in providing lifesaving assistance to the migrants currently hosted in the government-led site of Masagara, and the migrants that will be gathered in Ali-Sabieh, in the form of provision of emergency shelter and NFIs in coordination with the other UN-agencies involved.

description.narrative: As displaced communities in Cabo Delgado and Nampula remain vulnerable to natural disasters and conflict, IOM's intervention directly contributes to increase the preparedness future disasters through pre-positioning of non-food item (NFI) stock and strengthening of the assessment capacity for natural disaster risk analysis and data made available through the Displacement Tracking Matrix (DTM) in Cabo Delgado. In light of the global COVID-19 pandemic, and the large-scale migratory in-flow of Mozambicans workers returning from South Africa, Zimbabwe, and other neighbouring countries, as a result of lock-downs or other restrictive policies, a crisis modifier will enable IOM to quickly activate and deploy resources at key border crossing points, return communities and, to the extent possible, in internal displaced person's settlement in central areas of the country, in efforts to prevent and mitigate associated risks of communal transmission.

This project focuses on strategic priorities at the community, national and regional levels. In the context of the pandemic, these programs support humanitarian actors in identifying priority areas for COVID-19 preparedness, including the decongestion of crowded IDP sites at risk for the spread of COVID-19.

Strengthening COVID-19 Preparedness and Response in North-East Nigeria Through Targeted Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH) Activities

description.narrative: Through this project, IOM aims to support the reduction in vulnerabilities of crisis affected populations in north-east Nigeria against COVID-19 and contribute to the containment of the spread of the COVID-19 pandemic. To achieve this objective, IOM is strengthening COVID-19 preparedness and response efforts in the area of water, sanitation and hygiene (WASH) in camps and camp-like settings, and surrounding host communities. Activities include hygiene promotion, sensitization and community engagement, provision of clean and safe water, distribution of essential hygiene and cleaning items, care and maintenance of sanitation facilities, installation of handwashing stations, and management of the WASH core pipeline to ensure a steady stream of core relief supplies to partners for distribution to the affected population.

title.narrative: Multisectoral Humanitarian Assistance for Displaced and Mobile Populations in Sudan

description.narrative: The aim of this project is to contribute towards efforts to address urgent humanitarian needs through a multi-sectoral approach focused on providing integrated support to displaced and vulnerable crisis-affected populations. To achieve this aim, the project will focus on three inter-related outcomes centered on i) collecting and sharing with partners’ up-to-date information needed to respond effectively to humanitarian needs; ii) providing emergency shelter and non-food items to vulnerable populations; and, iii) mitigating potential causes of tension and conflict (resource-driven and inter-community) by promoting peaceful co-existence through improved access to basic services and livelihood opportunities. As the recent outbreak of COVID-19 is further exacerbating an already stretched health system and worsening an already dire economic situation, the project will include mainstreamed and dedicated activities to respond to the COVID-19 outbreak in particular with regards to health and livelihoods but also water, sanitation and hygiene activities.

title.narrative: Provision of Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH) Services Targeting Displaced Populations Hosted in Camp and Camp-like Settings and Hosting Communities in North-East Nigeria

description.narrative: In response to the needs that have been identified by the water, sanitation, and hygiene (WASH) Sector and in line with the Nigeria Humanitarian Fund Allocation Strategy, this project will support the continuation and scaling-up of WASH assistance in camp and camp-like setting and in hosting communities. The project will address access to safe water through the care and maintenance of existing boreholes, improved sanitation through the construction and maintenance of shower and latrine blocks with handwashing stations, enhanced cholera preparedness and response and overall improved hygiene through increased awareness on hygiene, COVID-19 and cholera prevention through targeted messaging, as well as solid waste management. Cholera messaging will be extended to host communities, who will benefit indirectly from the other forms of assistance as well. To ensure a timely and holistic response to the multi-sectoral needs of displaced populations in camps and camp-like settings, the activities will be implemented in conjunction with other components of IOM’s emergency response for an integral response.

title.narrative: IOM Ethiopia Funding Requirement for the COVID-19 Preparedness and Response

description.narrative: COVID-19 pandemic continues to present unprecedented impacts on Ethiopian society. Ethiopia's Planning and Development Commission (PDC), the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and the UN all expect COVID-19 to pose major adverse impacts on the economy as well as on household welfare and human dignity due to low economic growth, close of businesses, and reduced productivity in key sectors such as agriculture and services. The pandemic has also heightened existing vulnerabilities among highly vulnerable groups. Ethiopian migrants who end up stranded in countries from in the Horn of Africa and the Gulf. The proposed project aims to contribute to a well-coordinated, informed, and timely response to COVID-19 in Gambella and Tigray Regional States. For this, IOM is: 1) Enhancing the capacity of Humera and Pagak points of entry (POE) in the areas of surveillance, Infection Prevention and Control (IPC) and risk communication; 2) Empowering individuals and communities to adopt preventative and health seeking behaviours necessary for reducing the spread of the coronavirus; and 3) improving access to non-food items (NFIs) and essential health and protection services for targeted returnees, refugees, and asylum seekers.

title.narrative: IOM Crisis Response Platform
Strengthening the Disaster Response and Preparedness Capacity in Niger through the Construction of a Multi-purpose Evacuation Site

description.narrative: Since 2011, the Séno site located in the suburbs of Niamey has been designated by the Government of Niger as a temporary emergency evacuation site for flood victims. More recently, in the context of the COVID-19 pandemic, it is being used to accommodate the Nigerien returnees for their quarantine. However, due to the rainy season and the sandstorms, many of the emergency shelters have been damaged and require continuous reparations. Also, the site is facing many electricity as well as water, sanitation and hygiene (WASH) related challenges due to poor drainage. Floods represent a recurrent phenomenon in Niamey and other parts of Niger, which require dedicated and adequate solutions for systematic evacuation options. In addition, the COVID-19 pandemic triggered heavy operational challenges to IOM’s assisted voluntary return assistance to stranded migrants. Temporary shelter solutions for returning migrants from Niger to their countries of origin are necessary, while ensuring adherence to the required public health measures to prevent the spread of COVID-19. Capitalizing on the Séno site experience described above, there is an urgent need to build a multi-purpose site that would meet the quarantine and isolation minimum standards in terms of site management, site design and first aid needs.

title.narrative: COVID-19 Response for Vulnerable Displaced Communities in Mindanao

description.narrative: IOM is providing life-saving assistance to internally displaced persons (IDPs) and returnees in the Philippines. In particular, IOM is ensuring that at-risk communities, including IDPs and returnees, are better prepared to COVID-19 through improved access to water, sanitation and hygiene (WASH) by constructing and maintaining key WASH and COVID-19 preparedness facilities, as well as providing critical equipment for safer cold chain management and promoting hygiene and awareness-raising in displacement sites. In addition, IOM aims at meeting the most urgent WASH and shelter needs of persons in vulnerable situations through cash and in-kind assistance. Through this approach, the project contributes to the long-term goal that regional and community preparedness and resilience of Mindanao is improved for potential future pandemics, as the socio-economic and physical impact of COVID-19 on at-risk communities in Mindanao is mitigated.

description.narrative: This project builds the technical capacity of the Afghan Ministry of Refugees and Repatriation (MoRR) on information management through the development and roll out of the Afghan Returnee Information System (ARIS) at four major border crossing points with Iran and Pakistan. This will facilitate the registration of all returning Afghans from which returnee certificates are issued, which then grants access to additional rights inclusive of land allocation schemes. IOM also supports the development of a reintegration referral mechanism at the provincial level in 12 provinces of high return from the initial phase now scaled up to 25 total provinces. IOM has established Reintegration Information Centers (RICs) to carry out secondary reintegration registration. The collected information is presented at monthly Provincial Reintegration Committee (PRC) meetings- multi-stakeholder forums attended by government agencies, UN and NGO partners to provide assistance and referrals to returnees. Given the COVID-19 pandemic a top up funding amount has been given to for migration health and DTM components under the original grant to address health screening/surveillance at points of entry, Risk Communication and Community Engagement (RCCE), and continuity of basic primary health care services to underserved and marginalized migrant populations.

title.narrative: Capacity Building in Migration and Border Management in Guinea (CBMBM)

description.narrative: The overall goal of the project is to promote state and human security in Guinea by supporting law enforcement agencies to be more effective, accountable, and inclusive. Up to 4 border posts will be renovated or built and equipped with radios in the targeted areas. Through a series of capacity building activities, law enforcement agents will be trained to detect fraudulent travel documents, identify suspicious cases, and aware of the need to protect migrants. A comprehensive border assessment will be produced. Data and information on cross-border migration will be collected and analyzed by the border posts equipped with advanced data collecting system such as the Migration Information Data Analysis System and the installation of Flow Monitoring Points. Border agents will receive several trainings on data collection, use of data protection and privacy. The Government of Guinea will have increased capacity to collect, manage and analyse information on cross-border movement and develop evidence-based migration policies, as well as capacities to adapt their work to the COVID-19 context.

title.narrative: Enhancing Social Stability through Border Communities’ Empowerment in Guinea

description.narrative: The goal of the project is to promote state and human security and enhance social cohesion around targeted Guinea border communities by supporting law enforcement agencies and border communities to be more effective, accountable, and inclusive. More specifically, the approach aims to strengthen Guinea’s national border and migration management capacities and, in turn, support the Government of Guinea’s commitment to facilitate the orderly flow of people and goods across the borders and to while reinforcing border community stability, amid COVID-19. The project equally aims at reinforcing the capacities of cross border communities in rural areas through community based early warning conflict alert system and the cross-border collaboration alongside Guinea-Liberia and Côte d’Ivoire borders.

title.narrative: Strengthening the Republic of Moldova’s National Response to the COVID-19 Crisis

description.narrative: The overall objective of the project is to ensure effective and accessible health service for COVID-19 patients in Moldova, with a focus on vulnerable groups. In order to achieve this objective, the project activities will allow improving access to personal protective equipment (PPE) for front line workers in the health system and non-health agencies (police, penitentiaries, etc.) to ensure the efficient and safe provision of public services during the COVID-19 crisis. Additionally, it will assist most vulnerable categories and their dependents with immediate supplies (e.g. food and sanitizers). The project will enhance the capacities of the border police in the points of entry to ensure infection control and management.

title.narrative: Mekong Region: Responding to Cross-Border Mobility Challenges at Points of Entry During the COVID-19 Outbreak

description.narrative: This project seeks to contribute to effective control of COVID-19 transmission across the Greater Mekong Region countries (i.e. Cambodian, Myanmar, Lao People's Democratic Republic, Viet Nam and Thailand). Its main focus is to target points of entry (PoEs) by enhancing capacity of border officials, reducing risks at PoEs and supporting vulnerable migrants in order to ensure safe, regular and humane migration. The project builds on three interrelated components to be implemented across all target countries including (1) procurement and distribution of appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE) for relevant frontline immigration officials and health staff at the PoE, according to WHO Standards and national guidelines; (2) capacity development for immigration authorities to implement health-compliant border procedures; and (3) information, education and communication material for migrants. In addition, intervention on special measures for migrants in immigration detention centres will be implemented in Thailand, where IOM Thailand current works to improve the situation of vulnerable migrants who are placed in detention centres operated by the Royal Thai Government.

title.narrative: Improving Epidemiological Surveillance for COVID 19 through an Inclusive Community Level Response in Mauritania

description.narrative: This multi-agency project will intervene in three different areas, namely Nationwide Watch, Field Epidemiology and Case Management. For localities where an official point of entry (POE) is established and still functioning, community surveillance will be carried out in close collaboration with IOM and local authorities, who will provide the POE with the necessary capacity to carry out surveillance of suspicious health cases. IOM will train the border agents on the establishment of health measures to reduce the risks of spreading of COVID-19 and provide specific equipment and supplies for their implementation noting the need to consider protection and rights of women and girls. IOM will also assist the border agents posted at POE in establishing a Community Watch and Alert Committee (CWAC) with the border communities, respectful of age and gender specific consideration and support the POE in coordinating their response with regional health authorities (DRAS).

title.narrative: IOM Crisis Response Platform
Immediate Response to COVID-19 Pandemic for Effective Border Management in Nigeria

description.narrative: IOM in anticipation of the opening of the airspaces, proposes to equip the selected points of entries (PoEs) with necessary personal protective equipment (PPE) and other tools necessary for adequate border management through a public health emergency lens. In line with the National COVID-19 Multi-Sectorial Pandemic Response Plan's pillar on PoEs, IOM seeks to strengthen and increase surveillance at PoEs, including capacity building of the relevant PoE entities. The Nigeria Centre for Disease Control has in this Response Plan detailed the type of PPEs and materials that the Port Health Services (PHS) and the Nigeria Immigration Service (NIS) would need to adequately protect themselves while in the line of duty as front-line workers. Central to infection, prevention and control (IPC) is the strengthening of weak water sanitation and hygiene (WASH) systems at PoEs, in some instances, these are non-existent and will need to be established. WASH systems play an important role in IPC, and it is important to ensure that PoEs are decked out with the necessary infrastructure to ensure that IPC is effectively conducted. To complement all the aforementioned interventions, IOM will seek to provide the PHS with computers to enable them to establish electronic system for adequate border management.

title.narrative: Support of Points of Entries into Cameroon through the Reinforcement of the Border Management System in its Attempt to Tackle the Transmission of COVID-19

description.narrative: The intervention will seek to improve the capacity of the border management system in its effort to mitigate the propagation of COVID-19. Following assessments at points of entries (PoEs), it was determined that the border agents lack the requirement equipment (handwashing facilities) and supplies (gloves, eye protection, facemasks) to properly process the movements of merchandise and travelers. Additionally, there is an urgent need of accurate data on events related to COVID-19 in the three targeted provinces bordering Cameroon and Central African Republic. Even though these borders are opened for only commercial purposes, Chadian nationals are still entering Chad and quarantined at PoEs for two weeks where they do not have the support to meet their daily needs and are forced to discreetly leave their quarantine locations. The project intends to support the government in information management by conducting data collection mainly on observed flow at PoEs, profiles and needs of quarantined individuals, preventive measures in place at PoEs and COVID-19 related knowledge at PoEs.

title.narrative: Strengthening Fiji's Border Management Capacity

description.narrative: Fiji is a relatively high mobility country, having the second highest number of immigrants in the Pacific. The Fiji Department of Immigration (DoI) is the main government agency responsible for overseeing immigration and border management efforts in the country. The objective of the project is to contribute to the Government of Fiji achieving strengthened migration governance through enhancing border security and travel facilitation, which aligns with targets under Fiji’s 5-year National Development Plan. The proposed project will provide technical support, including capacity development and training on process improvement, policy development, data sharing, administrative streamlining, and mentoring. It will also assist the DoI in reviewing its response to the COVID-19 pandemic and identifying opportunities for improvements and better coordination with other government entities such as the Ministry of Health and Medical Services. Through this technical support, the project aims to increase Fiji’s capacity to effectively manage its borders while improving national security and economic opportunities for the country.
